column1: Total abdominal colectomy is the removal of the large intestine from the lowest part of the small intestine (ileum) to the rectum.

The procedure is done for people who have: - Crohn disease that has not spread to the rectum or the anus - Many colon cancer tumors, when the rectum is not affected - Severe constipation, called colonic inertia

Ask your health care provider about these possible complications: Risks for any surgery are: - Blood clots in the legs that may travel to the lungs - Breathing problems - Infection, including in the lungs, urinary tract, and belly - Heart attack or stroke Risks for this surgery are: - Bleeding inside your belly - Damage to nearby organs in the body - Scar tissue may form in the belly and cause a blockage of the small intestine - Leakage of stool from the connection between the small intestine and the rectum.
